results.notes: I had not noticed the small growths on the stipe of obs 465899 when I laid it onto a microscope slide to print. When I scoped the spore drop, there was an area on the slide where angular spores had collected. Then, whe I looked atthe photos of the Gymnopus fruit body, I noticed the presence of what appears to be Syzygospora on the stipe and gills. But, the angular spores do not point toward Syzygospora. Could at least one of these parasitic growths represent a species of Claudopus (ie. the small parasitic “Entoloma” species)? Perhaps there’s more than one parasitic fungus on the Gymnopus.
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1395/2021_DSC4091
Habitat: grassland, former pasture, 15 m away of mixed forest edge; slightly inclined mountain slope, south-east aspect; calcareous, colluvial, skeletal, water permeable ground; dry and sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 625 m (2.050 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, Na Melu place, on the upper part of a former pasture next to Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Leccinellum pseudoscabrum (until 2017 named Leccinum pseudoscabrum) is a rather common mushroom in Slovenia. It can be found under hornbeam trees (genus Carpinus) or more rarely under hazel (Corylus avellana) in contrast to very similar Leccinum scabrum, which grows under birches (genus Betula). For both species, there are very few exceptions known from these tight mycorrhizal relations.

This find is interesting in respect to mycorrhiza. There are no Carpinus or Betula trees known as far as a few km away from this find. The closest single Corylus avellana in the vicinity grows 17 m away within the forest edge. It has poorly developed canopy, is about 4 m tall with three – four trunks of 5-7 cm in diameter. It seems impossible that its root system would reach the site of the find. The forest edge near the site is composed of several large Ostrya carpinifolia (15 m away), several large Fagus sylvatica trees (22+ m away), a single Fraxinus excelsior (18 m away, trunk diameter 15 cm) and several small Picea abies. All these trees appear much too far for mycorrhiza with this find. Closer to the find are: a large Picea abies (6.5 m away, trunk diameter 60 cm), a small Frangula alnus = Rhamnus frangula (about 5 m away and 3 m tall, trunk diameter about 10 cm), a small Fraxinus ornus (also about 5 m away, 7 m tall, trunk diameter 15 cm) and a small Fagus sylvatica (about 8 m away, trunk diameter 17 cm, canopy diameter about 3 m). Picea abies is out of consideration regarding mycorrhiza. Neither Frangula alnus nor Fraxinus ornus appear in the literature (accessible to me) as possible mycorrhizal partner of Leccinellum pseudoscabrum or Leccinum scabrum. The root system of the small Fagus sylvatica apparently does not reach the spot. So, what is the mycorrhizal partner in this case remains open.

Another strange thing is that the ground on which the fungus was found is dry, highly water permeable, colluvial and skeletal. That is in strong opposition to fresh, moister, usually clayey ground typical for Leccinellum pseudoscabrum. Also, violet tint of blackening after bruising or cutting the mushroom, described in several sources, was not present. Bruising was directly to blackish with no other color tints. May be this determination is wrong? If so, I have no clue, what else can this find be. All other observed traits correspond to Leccinellum pseudoscabrum very well.
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes: The past few years I’ve been finding “sulphur tufts” with small caps and thin stipes (like these). I’ve wondered if perhaps H. subviride has been spreading northward. But, the small spores seen here (lengths up to about 7 microns) support a proposal of H. fascisulare.

results.notes:
On hardwood log, beech and oak being nearby candidates.
Notes from Django Grootmyers: “Growing on the side of a hardwood log near Quercus sect. Quercus, Carya sp., Fagus grandifolia, Carpinus caroliniana, Liriodendron tulipifera, Ilex opaca, Asimina triloba, Broussonetia papyrifera and a dead standing Juniperus virginiana. Caps not hygrophanous; 2.1 to 16.6 mm wide and 1.0 to 2.5 mm tall. Stems 6.9 to 8.4 mm long and 1.1 to 2.0 mm wide. Surfaces not fluorescing. Odor not distinctive. Taste initially farinose, slowly becoming strongly peppery. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia abundant and fusiform, containing brown-pigemented granules in Melzer’s reagent. Spore print pinkish brown. Spores warty. Spore measurements taken from a spore print. Spore measurements: 5.3 – 6.8 (7.6) × (3.7) 3.8 – 4.5 (4.8) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30; Me = 6 × 4.1 µm; Qe = 1.5.”

results.notes:
Hornbeam, redcedar, tulip poplar, sourwood, hickory.
Notes from Django Grootmyers: “Growing in leaf litter near Quercus sect. Quercus, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carpinus caroliniana, Fagus grandifolia, Oxydendron arboreum, Ilex opaca, Sassafras albidum, Prunus serotina and Acer sp. Caps pale greyish brown to pale brown with darker centers; and silky-fibrillose; one slighlty rimose; parabolic to conic; 5.3 to 9.5 mm wide and 3.4 to 3.9 mm tall. Gills adnexed and even with 2 to 3 tiers of lamellulae. Stems smooth and apically pruinose; white toward the cap and becoming pale very pale brown toward the base; with white basal mycelium; 25.9 to 38.7 mm long and 0.6 to 0.9 mm wide. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis a cutis with scattered clamps. Caulocystidia absent. Lactifers present in the stipe trama. Clamps scattered in the lamellar trama. Subhymeninum composed of short-celled hyphae. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline; smooth; mostly lageniform with some utriform orfusiform; apices often slightly moniliform or with slight bumpy lateral outgrowths; some secondarily simple-septate and constricted; not basally clamped. Cheilocystidia measurements: (32.2) 39.8 – 69.1 (80) × (10) 11.6 – 20.6 (22.6) µm; Q = (2.1) 2.9 – 4.7 (6); N = 30; Me = 54.5 × 14.8 µm; Qe = 3.8. Basidia 4-sterigmate; clavate to cylindrical; not basally clamped. Basidia measurements: (21.9) 28.5 – 36.1 (37.1) × (11) 11.9 – 14 (14.5) µm; Q = (2) 2.2 – 2.8 (2.9); N = 20; Me = 31.8 × 13 µm; Qe = 2.4. Spores cuboid to 5-sided. Spore measurements: (10.2) 10.6 – 12.2 (13.6) × (8.9) 9.4 – 10.6 (11.6) µm; Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.3 (1.4); N = 30; Me = 11.5 × 10 µm; Qe = 1.2”

—

results.notes:
Very beautiful and unfamiliar. Under umbrella magnolia, buckeye, sycamore.
Notes from Django Grootmyers:
“Growing singly in soil near decorticated hardwood log. Fagus grandifolia, Quercus spp., Ostrya virginiana, Ilex opaca, Asimina triloba, Magnolia acuminata, Aesculus sp. and Acer sp. present nearby. Cap pale purple, dry and finely fibrillose; 14.4 mm wide and 6.9 mm tall. Gills pale pink, adnexed and even with 3 to 4 tiers of lamellulae. 12 full-length lamellulae reaching the stem. Stem striate with white pruina apically; dry; even; fragile; with white basal mycelium and attached to white rhizomorphs; 44.7 mm long and 1.5 mm wide. Cap and stem context white to very pale gray. Cap context very thin. Odor very slightly spermatic. Pileipellis a cutis with clamps, encrusting and intracellular pigments. Clamps present in the stipe trama. Caulocystidia present. Cheilocystidia present. Spores angular. Spore measurements: (6.4) 7.3 – 8.3 (8.9) × (4.8) 4.9 – 5.9 (6.5) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.3 – 1.6 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 7.7 × 5.3 µm; Qe = 1.4”

results.notes: I noticed the bright color of this “Chicken of the Woods” (Laetiporus sulphureus) jump out at me from the edge of some woods as I was driving past this morning. It was about seven feet off the ground in a big old oak but I was determined to collect it, along with some of the wood substrate since I thought it would make a nice display. Naturally, by the time I could get back out there it was afternoon, 90+ degrees, and the sun was shining right on the spot. About 30 minutes of determined sawing with a small pruning saw on a 6 foot extension pole did the trick! Score!

results.notes:
Habitat: bottomland pine/hemlock/deciduous grove, on soil or pine cone
Cap: diameters to 2.5 cm, broadly umbonate, dry, radially fibrillose with white fibrils and decorated with upright tufts of dark fibrils, radially striate
Gills: close, free, +lamellulae, edges smooth
Stipe: length 4-5.5 cm, width 2 mm, expanding slightly downwards above a modestly clavate base, dry, smooth, hollow
Partial veil: grommet-like, upper surface white and smooth, lower surface fuzzy, upper and lower edges fringed, white or slightly browning below
Flesh: thin, white, nonstaining
Odor: none
This seems close to Lepiota phaeosstictiformis, but that species is not reported to have a striate cap.

results.notes:
Collected by Susan Hopkins. Caps hemispheric to plane; dull reddish-brown with a granular coating and rugose centers; 31.6 to 60.7 mm wide and 8.9 to 15.6 mm tall. Gills adnexed and entire. Stems tapered toward the bases with raised granular annuli; 18.7 to 23.2 mm long and 13.1 to 18.0 mm wide at the widest. Cap and stem context white and staining light brown when cut. Hollow pocket toward center of stem. Surfaces not bruising. Odor not distinctive. Taste farinose. All lamellar structures inamyloid. Pileipellis cells reddish brown in 1M KOH. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth and hyaline. Spore measurements: (2.9) 3.3 – 4 (4.4) × (1.8) 2.1 – 2.8 (3) µm, Q = (1.2) 1.4 – 1.8 (1.9); N = 30, Me = 3.7 × 2.4 µm; Qe = 1.5.

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing in coarse sand on the margin of Coopers Rd. to the NW of Pakim Pond.
I don’t recognize this species, never saw it before at BBSF or anywhere else during my 10+ years of visiting the NJ Pine Barrens (I don’t think this is A. longipes). It appears to be a small-sized species, probably one of the smallest sect. Lepidella in my experience. I found another collection of it down the road – about 50-75 yards away – consisting of several basidiomata, and the largest one at about the same stage of development was about the same size (see obs 466844).
The visible morphology is well documented in the attached photos. The small size, the white woolly-felted to floccose volva breaking up into a dense network of patches on the cap surface and turning brown on the disk, the fibrous-floccose and rapidly evanescent partial veil and the densely woolly-floccose upper stipe (limbus internus?) are the salient features of this taxon. No odor was detected.
During the stipe expansion, the outer layer of tissue in the middle of the stipe cracked, giving the impression of a limbate volva. The cross-sectional photo shows no saccate/limbate volva.
Overall fruitbody height = 7 cm; cap footprint = 4.5 cm; cap flesh = 8 mm thick above stipe; gills = 5.5 mm wide; stipe = 6.2 cm long, 1 cm wide at apex and gradually expanding to 1.2 cm just above the bulb; bulb = 2.7 cm long, 1.7 cm wide. The spores appear high-end elongate to cylindric at x400 with no mounting agent; detailed measurements to be posted later.

results.notes:
A single fruitbody growing in shade on the side of a road cutting through a cedar swamp. There were a couple of pitch pines (undoubtedly the host trees) nearby, but no oaks.
Overall fruitbody height ~ 6 cm. Cap 7-7.5 cm wide (footprint), scarlet red with a mottled creamy-yellowish disk; cuticle dull, rough, somewhat finely granular, dry, not viscid, peeled ~1/3 at best; cap margin faintly striate and subtly tuberculate; cap flesh 7.5 mm thick above stipe. Gills 5.5 mm wide, appearing whitish to pale cream (spore print color probably B-D in Kibby Fatto), close but not crowded, not forking, with plentiful lamellulae of variable lengths. Stipe 5 cm long and uniformly 2 cm wide, surface longitudinally textured and faintly flushed with pink here and there, not staining when handled. Cap and stipe flesh firm despite being a bit wormy, not staining when exposed to air. Odor nill to faintly smokey(?). Taste mild and pleasant (not chalky).
Based on the above characters interpreted with a bit of flexibility in stipe and spore print colors, this russula has the following codes in Kibby-Fatto book:
A = red cap
H = peels up to 1/3
K/L = stem white (K) or with just a flush of color (L)
N = cap 4-10 cm wide
P/Q = spore print pale cream to pale ochre
T = mild taste
Not surprisingly I couldn’t key it out definitively. In particular, the coniferous association was problematic. The closest hits are R. cremeirosea and R. peckii. Another possibility is R. subfloridana obtained from the southern species list.
Specimen preserved and fresh tissue in SDS buffer (vial #94).
DNA Sequencing Update (posted on 21-Nov-23):
The fresh tissue in buffer never got sequenced, but a dry voucher sample was eventually submitted to Steve Russell for ONT-nanopore sequencing. The derived full-length sequence has a high RiC index of 243; it’s uploaded to this post.
There are several accession of this species in GenBank, as demonstrated by their 99.2-99.8% similarity to this ITS sequence. The species distribution range based on the accession metadata is southeastern Canada south to Tennessee and west to Michigan; some vouchers possibly came from Massachusetts and Ohio. The Canadian accession, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/OQ322226, calls this species Russula pulchra. The other accessions are not named and Steve’s “sp-IN110” is not there either (must be a code in his internal database). The overall description of R. pulchra in Kibby/Fatto is in good agreement with the morphology of my specimen, including the odor and taste, but the habitat indicated in K/F (“deciduous woods, especially under beech”) is very different from the Pinelands ecology my specimen came from.

results.notes:
Mixed woods; hemlock, oak, birch.
The heavy gray universal veil material on the cap, the seeming lack of rubescence on the fruit body (at the time it was collected), and the thin gray flocculence on the stipe brought to my mind this obs 147255. I did not get the fruit body into my dehydrator until 8 hours after it was collected. By that time reddish-brown staining had developed on both the exterior and interior of the stipe base. This eventual rubescence points away from the currently held concept of A. maryaliceae. But, I still havta wonder about this one. It looks like 147255 (linked above).

results.notes:
Found by Django Grootmyers. No Eastern records on MyCoPortal!
Notes from Django Grootmyers: “Growing on bits of twigs, bark, hardwood leaf litter and old Vitis fruit stems in a stand of Rhododendron sp. and Vitis sp. vines near Carpinus caroliniana, Tsuga canadensis and Acer sp. Caps cylindric to parabolic; smooth; dry; sulcate-striate; 1.4 to 3.2 mm wide and 1.7 to 3.6 mm tall. Stems smooth and even with pale brown strigose basal mycelium; 12.9 to 33.9 mm long and 0.2 mm wide. Odor and taste not distinctive. Pileipellis a cutis with brown intracellular pigment. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia scattered and ellipsoid. Cheilocystidia measurements: 15.3 – 26.3 × (9.2) 9.24 – 14.4 µm; Q = 1.6 – 2.2; N = 3; Me = 20.6 × 11.1 µm; Qe = 1.9. Spores weakly initially amyloid and remaining so after 30 min, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measuerments: (6) 6.4 – 8.6 (8.9) × (3.2) 3.6 – 4.3 (4.7) µm; Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 2.1; N = 30; Me = 7.5 × 3.9 µm; Qe = 1.9”

—

results.notes:
Some with a strong melon/cucumber smell, some without. In moss on the base of a large basswood.
Notes from Django Grootmyers:
“Growing in soil among moss at the base of a large Tilia americana near Carpinus caroliniana, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Acer sp. and Rhododendron sp. Caps glabrous and hygrophanous; 4.0 to 6.0 mm wide and 1.7 to 3.8 mm tall. Gills adnate to short decurrent with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae. Stems pruinose at apices and smooth below with white basal mycelium and attached to white rhizomorphs; even; 16.1 to 23.0 mm long and0.5 to 0.8 mm wide. Odor and taste farinose. Spore print pinkish brown. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores bumpy and angular, but not strongly. Spore measurements: (4.6) 4.8 – 5.6 (6.5) × (3) 3.2 – 3.7 (3.9) µm; Q = (1.4) 1.42 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30; Me = 5.3 × 3.5 µm; Qe = 1.5”

results.notes:
Alone on needles and moss under Abies.
Cap 2.8 cms., light brown radially fibrous, with cuticle hanging over the edge, whiter fibrils on the margin; gills notched, broad, gill edges paler, fimbriated; stipe 4 x40 mm., brown, equal, curved, covered with white fibrils.
Spores of variable shape and size, the smaller ones ovate/cylindric, (12.3-13.5 × 5.1-5.5) and the larger, torpedo shape (15-21 × 5.3-6.8); pleurocystidia (54-58 × 13-15.1), subfusiform or lageniform with a short neck and a few crystals on apex.

results.notes:
The combination of shiny brown “fulvum” cap that lacks scales together with yellow gills is distinctive.
Gills were more strikingly yellow when seen first-hand.
Champignons du Quebec calls this “Tricholoma fulvum ss. Ovrebo” https://www.mycoquebec.org/... MO would not allow me to use this name. Neither did MO allow me to use the name “Tricholoma fulvum group”, so I settled for “Tricholoma fulvum”, which is a species that has white gills. I don’t know what “ss. Ovrebo” means.
